summary:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this document about Canadian Hydro Developers. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The document mentions that Canadian Hydro Developers was a Canadian company with 12 hydroelectric, 8 wind, and 1 biomass site. Founded by John and Ross Keating with Jack McCleary. They started in 1989 with $1.3 million and a contract with TransAlta. They used revenue from their plants to fund future projects. 

Then there are acquisitions: they bought CREC in 2005, Vector Wind Energy in 2006, and GW Power Corporation in 2007. In 2009, TransAlta acquired them for $5.25 per share. 

The generating facilities section lists all their sites with details like location, fuel type, capacity, and dates. There are hydro, wind, and one biomass plant. Some wind farms have specific turbine models and capacities. 

The main topic is the company's operations, growth through acquisitions, and their energy facilities. Key concepts include their expansion strategy, types of energy sources, and the acquisition by TransAlta. I need to condense this into 3-5 sentences, focusing on the main points. Make sure to mention the founders, the types of facilities, acquisitions, and the acquisition by TransAlta. Also, note the transition from hydro to including wind and biomass. Avoid too many details on each facility but highlight the key numbers like 12 hydro, 8 wind, 1 biomass. Mention the key acquisitions and the final sale to TransAlta. Keep it concise.
</think>

Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc., founded in 1989 by John and Ross Keating with Jack McCleary, operated 12 hydroelectric, 8 wind, and 1 biomass power sites in Canada, expanding through strategic acquisitions like Canadian Renewable Energy Corporation (2005), Vector Wind Energy (2006), and GW Power Corporation (2007). The company focused on renewable energy, leveraging revenue from early hydro projects to fund growth, and diversified into wind power with facilities like the 197.8 MW Wolfe Island Wind Project. In 2009, TransAlta acquired the firm for $5.25 per share, marking the end of its independent operations. Its generating facilities included run-of-river hydro plants, wind farms with turbines from brands like GE and Nordex, and a biomass site in Alberta.

qa_pairs.reasoning: The question asks for the name of the Canadian company operating specific power sites. Sentence [S1] explicitly states 'Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc. was a Canadian company that operated 12 hydroelectric power sites, eight wind power sites and one biomass power site in Canada.' This directly matches the question's requirements, making [S1] the correct citation. Other sentences provide additional context but do not contain the exact information about the company's operational scope.
qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Canadian Hydro Developers


# Canadian Hydro Developers



**Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc.** was a Canadian company that operated 12 hydroelectric power sites, eight wind power sites and one biomass power site in Canada. [S2] Canadian Hydro was founded by two brothers John and Ross Keating with Jack McCleary. [S3] In 1989 Canadian Hydro had secured $1.3 million in equity and a contract with TransAlta to build three small run-of-river facilities. [S4] Revenue from these plants were then used in part to finance the future plants. [S5] In January 2005, the firm bought Canadian Renewable Energy Corporation (CREC). [S6] In December 2006 the firm bought Vector Wind Energy
which has over 13 projects either built or in the process as of 2007. [S7] Announced in February 2007 (and finalized in March) the firm bought GW Power Corporation. [S8] In December 2009 TransAlta acquired Canadian Hydro Developers at $5.25 cash per share. [S9] ## Generating facilities

All facilities are owned by Canadian Hydro Developers. [S10] | Name | Location | Fuel | Units net capacity (Date) | Capacity (net MW) | Link |

| Appleton | Appleton, Ontario | Hydro | * Run-of-river (1994) |

| Cowley North | Pincher Creek, Alberta | Wind power | * 15 Nordex N60 1.3 MW turbines (2001) | 19.5 MW |

| St. [S11] Mary | St. [S12] Mary, Alberta | Hydro | * Run-of-river |
| Taylor | Magrath, Alberta | Hydro | * Run-of-river |
| Taylor Wind Plant | Magrath, Alberta | Wind power | * 9 Kennetech 375 kW turbines (2004) | 3.4 MW |
| Upper Mamquam | Squamish, British Columbia | Hydro | * operational in 2005 | 25 MW |

**Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc.** was a Canadian company that operated 12 hydroelectric power sites, eight wind power sites and one biomass power site in Canada. [S2] Canadian Hydro was founded by two brothers John and Ross Keating with Jack McCleary. [S3] In 1989 Canadian Hydro had secured $1.3 million in equity and a contract with TransAlta to build three small run-of-river facilities. [S4] Revenue from these plants were then used in part to finance the future plants. [S5] In January 2005, the firm bought Canadian Renewable Energy Corporation (CREC). [S6] In December 2006 the firm bought Vector Wind Energy
which has over 13 projects either built or in the process as of 2007. [S7] Announced in February 2007 (and finalized in March) the firm bought GW Power Corporation. [S8] In December 2009 TransAlta acquired Canadian Hydro Developers at $5.25 cash per share. [S9] ## Generating facilities

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Canadian Hydro Developers


# Canadian Hydro Developers



**Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc.** was a Canadian company that operated 12 hydroelectric power sites, eight wind power sites and one biomass power site in Canada. [S2] Canadian Hydro was founded by two brothers John and Ross Keating with Jack McCleary. [S3] In 1989 Canadian Hydro had secured $1.3 million in equity and a contract with TransAlta to build three small run-of-river facilities. [S4] Revenue from these plants were then used in part to finance the future plants. [S5] In January 2005, the firm bought Canadian Renewable Energy Corporation (CREC). [S6] In December 2006 the firm bought Vector Wind Energy
which has over 13 projects either built or in the process as of 2007. [S7] Announced in February 2007 (and finalized in March) the firm bought GW Power Corporation. [S8] In December 2009 TransAlta acquired Canadian Hydro Developers at $5.25 cash per share. [S9] ## Generating facilities
